'''Dan + Shay''' is an American [[country music]] duo composed of vocalists and songwriters Dan Smyers and Shay Mooney.<ref>{{cite web|first=Sarah|last=Wyland|url=http://blog.gactv.com/blog/2013/10/16/dan-shay-release-debut-single-to-country-radio/|title=Dan + Shay Release Debut Single To Country Radio | Great American Country|publisher=Blog.gactv.com|date=October 16, 2013|access-date=July 29, 2015|archive-date=November 2, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131102043353/http://blog.gactv.com/blog/2013/10/16/dan-shay-release-debut-single-to-country-radio/|url-status=dead}}</ref> They are signed to [[Warner Records|Warner Records Nashville]] and have released five albums, ''[[Where It All Began (Dan + Shay album)|Where It All Began]]'', ''[[Obsessed (Dan + Shay album)|Obsessed]]'', ''[[Dan + Shay (album)|Dan + Shay]]'', ''[[Good Things (Dan + Shay album)|Good Things]]'' and ''[[Bigger Houses]]''. Of their nine singles, five have topped the [[Country Airplay]] chart and three have topped the [[Hot Country Songs]] chart. The duo have collaborated with [[Justin Bieber]], [[Charlie Puth]], [[Rascal Flatts]], [[Lindsey Stirling]], [[RaeLynn]], and [[Kelly Clarkson]]. From 2019 to 2021, the duo won three consecutive [[Grammy Award for Best Country Duo/Group Performance|Grammy Awards for Best Country Duo/Group Performance]] for the songs "[[Tequila (Dan + Shay song)|Tequila]]", "[[Speechless (Dan + Shay song)|Speechless]]", and "[[10,000 Hours]]" (with Justin Bieber).

==Career==
===2013–2015: ''Where It All Began''===
{{Main|Where It All Began (Dan + Shay album)|l1=''Where It All Began'' (Dan + Shay album)}}
Before the duo's foundation, Mooney was a solo artist on [[T-Pain]]'s [[Nappy Boy Entertainment]] label and Smyers was a member of a group called Bonaventure as well as a previous member of the band Transition on [[Floodgate Records]].<ref name="taste">{{cite web|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/dan-and-shay-19-you-and-me/|title=Dan + Shay, '19 You + Me' [Listen]|work=Taste of Country|date=October 16, 2013|access-date=July 29, 2015|archive-date=September 3, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200903024511/https://tasteofcountry.com/dan-and-shay-19-you-and-me/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref name="Lenehan Vaughn">{{cite web|first=Grace|last=Lenehan Vaughn|url=https://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/10-things-you-may-not-know-about-dan-shay/|title=10 Things You May Not Know About Dan + Shay|work=Sounds Like Nashville|date=August 24, 2021|access-date=February 6, 2022|archive-date=February 6, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220206184314/https://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/10-things-you-may-not-know-about-dan-shay/|url-status=live}}</ref> The two met in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], in December 2012 at Dan's house during a party.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|first=Christina|last=Vinson|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/how-did-dan-and-shay-meet/|title=Dan-Shay Reveal How They Met ... in a Living Room Tent|work=Taste of Country|date=November 10, 2013|access-date=May 4, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111040255/https://tasteofcountry.com/how-did-dan-and-shay-meet/|archive-date=November 11, 2013|url-status=live}}</ref> There they would perform together for the first time and started writing the day after they met.<ref name="5 Things">{{cite news|first=Jess|last=Cohen|url=https://www.eonline.com/news/1025796/5-things-you-didn-t-know-about-dan-shay|title=5 Things You Didn't Know About Dan + Shay|work=[[E!]]|date=April 5, 2019|access-date=February 6, 2022}}</ref> The first song they ever wrote together got put on hold for [[Rascal Flatts]]. Within two months, the duo had multiple publishing offers and signed with [[Warner/Chappell Music]].<ref>{{cite magazine|first=Andrew|last=Hampp|url=http://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/5785939/inside-guy-oseary-and-paul-mcguinness-30m-live-nation-deal-new-roles-more|title=Inside Guy Oseary and Paul McGuinness' $30M Live Nation Deal|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=November 13, 2013|access-date=February 6, 2022|archive-date=June 7, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190607162328/https://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/5785939/inside-guy-oseary-and-paul-mcguinness-30m-live-nation-deal-new-roles-more|url-status=live}}</ref>

On October 14, 2013, the debut single, "[[19 You + Me]]", was released to country radio.<ref name="taste"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=7471|title=Dan + Shay offer debut single|work=[[Country Standard Time]]|date=October 15, 2013|access-date=November 11, 2022|archive-date=May 17, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230517025347/https://www.countrystandardtime.com/news/newsitem.asp?xid=7471|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|first=Gary|last=Trust|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/5762985/bubbling-under-glee-star-naya-rivera-graduates-to-first-solo-hit|title=Bubbling Under: 'Glee' Star Naya Rivera Graduates To First Solo Hit|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=October 18, 2013|access-date=November 11, 2022|archive-date=September 22, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200922063533/https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/5762985/bubbling-under-glee-star-naya-rivera-graduates-to-first-solo-hit|url-status=live}}</ref>  Dan + Shay wrote the song with Danny Orton. ===2015–2017: ''Obsessed''===
{{Main|Obsessed (Dan + Shay album)|l1=''Obsessed'' (Dan + Shay album)}}
In August 2015, the duo announced the Just the Right Kind of Crazy Tour across the Midwest and eastern United States.<ref name="2015 tour">{{cite web|first=Philip|last=Cosores|url=http://radio.com/2015/08/10/dan-shay-just-the-right-kind-of-crazy-tour/|title=Dan + Shay Announce 'Just The Right Kind of Crazy' Tour| publisher=Radio.com|date=August 13, 2015|access-date=February 6, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304113433/http://radio.com/2015/08/10/dan-shay-just-the-right-kind-of-crazy-tour/|archive-date=March 4, 2016|url-status=dead}}</ref> Their second album's first single, "[[From the Ground Up (song)|From the Ground Up]]", was released to country radio in February 2016. On June 3, 2016, the duo released their second studio album, ''[[Obsessed (Dan + Shay album)|Obsessed]]''.<ref name="AllMusic Obsessed">{{cite web|first=Stephen Thomas|last=Erlewine|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/obsessed-mw0002940668|title=Dan + Shay Obsessed|publisher=AllMusic|access-date=February 7, 2022|archive-date=February 8, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220208034000/https://www.allmusic.com/album/obsessed-mw0002940668|url-status=live}}</ref> The album's second single, "[[How Not To]]", was released to country radio on September 26, 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allaccess.com/country/future-releases|title=Future Release for Country Radio Stations|publisher=All Access Media Group|access-date=February 2, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160914072608/http://www.allaccess.com/country/future-releases|archive-date=September 14, 2016}}</ref> The duo joined [[Darius Rucker]] on his Good for a Good Time Tour from June - September 2016.<ref name="Good for a Good Time Tour 2016">{{cite web|first=Angela|last=Stefano|url=https://theboot.com/darius-rucker-dan-and-shay-michael-ray-2016-good-for-a-good-time-tour/|title=Darius Rucker Invites Dan + Shay, Michael Ray for 2016 Good for a Good Time Tour|work=The Boot|date=January 20, 2016|access-date=February 11, 2022|archive-date=February 12, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220212035316/https://theboot.com/darius-rucker-dan-and-shay-michael-ray-2016-good-for-a-good-time-tour/|url-status=live}}</ref> In November 2016, the duo started their The Obsessed Tour and continued to support it until April 2017.<ref name="The Obsessed Tour 2016-2017">{{cite web|first=Annie|last=Reuter|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/dan-and-shay-2017-obsessed-tour-dates/|title=Dan + Shay Extend Obsessed Tour into 2017|work=Taste of Country|date=November 16, 2016|access-date=February 11, 2022|archive-date=September 1, 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240901231349/https://tasteofcountry.com/dan-and-shay-2017-obsessed-tour-dates/|url-status=live}}</ref> It reached number one on the Country Airplay chart in July 2017. The album's third single, "[[Road Trippin' (Dan + Shay song)|Road Trippin']]", was released to country radio on July 17, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|first=Billy|last=Dukes|url=http://tasteofcountry.com/dan-and-shay-road-trippin/|title=Dan + Shay, 'Road Trippin'<nowiki/>' [Listen]|work=[[Taste of Country]]|date=June 20, 2017|access-date=February 2, 2022|archive-date=February 2, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220202222048/https://tasteofcountry.com/dan-and-shay-road-trippin/|url-status=live}}</ref> In 2017, the duo supported [[Thomas Rhett]] on his [[Home Team Tour]].<ref name="Home Team Tour">{{cite web|first=Jim|last=Casey|url=https://www.thecountrydaily.com/2017/06/20/thomas-rhett-extends-his-home-team-tour-with-more-fall-dates/|title=Thomas Rhett Extends His Home Team Tour With More Fall Dates|work=The Country Daily|date=June 20, 2017|access-date=February 11, 2022|archive-date=February 12, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220212035316/https://www.thecountrydaily.com/2017/06/20/thomas-rhett-extends-his-home-team-tour-with-more-fall-dates/|url-status=live}}</ref>

===2023–present: ''Bigger Houses''===
In July 2023, Dan + Shay revealed that they almost broke up after their 2021 tour. Dan Smyers stated, "I was in, like, the lowest low of my entire life. Came off the road, and I was like, 'Man, I f---ing hate music. I'm ready to quit".<ref>{{cite magazine|first=Jack|last=Irvin|url=https://people.com/dan-shay-almost-broke-up-after-wrapping-2021-tour-7558768|title=Dan + Shay Reveal They Almost Broke Up After Wrapping 2021 Tour: 'We Let Things Get in the Way'|magazine=[[People (magazine)|People]]|date=July 10, 2023|access-date=July 13, 2023|archive-date=July 14, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230714041540/https://people.com/dan-shay-almost-broke-up-after-wrapping-2021-tour-7558768|url-status=live}}</ref> They also confirmed their fifth studio album, ''[[Bigger Houses]]'' and released three singles, "[[Save Me the Trouble]]", "Bigger Houses", and "Heartbreak on the Map" on July 14, 2023. The album was released on September 15, 2023.<ref>{{cite web|first=Billy|last=Dukes|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/dan-and-shay-bigger-houses-album/|title=Dan + Shay Announce New ''Bigger Houses'' Album|work=Taste of Country|date=July 13, 2023|access-date=July 13, 2023|archive-date=July 14, 2023|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230714013511/https://tasteofcountry.com/dan-and-shay-bigger-houses-album/|url-status=live}}</ref>

The duo has cited many musical influences. Dan Smyers cited artists such as [[Ryan Adams]], [[Tom Petty]], [[Kenny Chesney]] and [[Alison Krauss]] as musical influences.<ref name=":1" /> Shay Mooney cited artists such as Rascal Flatts, [[Dave Matthews Band]], [[Usher (musician)|Usher]] and Kenny Chesney as musical influences.<ref name=":1" /> ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' noted musical influences from [[The Beach Boys]], [[Electric Light Orchestra]], [[Alan Jackson]] and [[Brooks & Dunn]] on the duo's fourth album, ''[[Good Things (Dan + Shay album)|Good Things]]''.<ref name="Billboard influences">{{cite magazine|first=Melinda|last=Newman|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/dan-shay-interview-good-things-album-9614833/|title=Dan + Shay Talk New Album, 'Good Things,' Writing with Shawn Mendes and Drake's Influence|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=August 13, 2021|access-date=February 11, 2022|archive-date=September 1, 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240901231351/https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/dan-shay-interview-good-things-album-9614833/|url-status=live}}</ref> According to Dan Smyers in an interview:

{{Blockquote|"We write country songs — the topline, the lyrics of these songs...We grew up listening to all kinds of music, not just country but pop, [[Rock music|rock]], R&B, [[Hip hop music|hip-hop]], everything… and you hear that in the music."<ref name="Billboard influences"/>}}

==Members==
===Dan Smyers===
[[File:Dan Smyers of Dan + Shay in 2017.jpg|thumb|upright=0.9|Dan Smyers]]
Daniel "Dan" Smyers, born {{birth date and age|1987|8|16|mf=y}}<ref name="cafenashville">{{cite web|url=https://www.cafenashville.com/artistprofiles/danandshay/|title=Dan + Shay - Cafe Nashville|website=Cafe Nashville|access-date=February 6, 2022|archive-date=February 6, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220206182810/https://www.cafenashville.com/artistprofiles/danandshay/|url-status=live}}</ref> was raised in [[Wexford, Pennsylvania]],<ref name="Grand Ole Opry">{{cite web |title=Dan + Shay - Grand Ole Opry |url=https://www.opry.com/artists/dan-shay/#:~:text=Dan%20%2B%20Shay%20Bio,-Website&text=Musical%20influences%20range%20from%20Ryan,he%20started%20learning%20the%20guitar. |access-date=February 11, 2022 |website=Opry |archive-date=February 12, 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220212043604/https://www.opry.com/artists/dan-shay/#:~:text=Dan%20%2B%20Shay%20Bio,-Website&text=Musical%20influences%20range%20from%20Ryan,he%20started%20learning%20the%20guitar. |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name="pittsburghmagazine">{{cite web|first=Tricia|last=Depres|url=https://www.pittsburghmagazine.com/you-should-know-dan-smyers/|title=You Should Know: Dan Smyers|work=Pittsburgh Magazine|date=February 19, 2015|access-date=February 6, 2022|archive-date=February 6, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220206182809/https://www.pittsburghmagazine.com/you-should-know-dan-smyers/|url-status=live}}</ref> where he attended [[North Allegheny Senior High School]].<ref>{{cite web|first=Aaron|last=Jentzen|url=http://www.pghcitypaper.com/pittsburgh/in-between/Content?oid=1337222|title=Local rockers Transition straddle commercialism and conviction'|publisher=Pghcitypaper.com|date=June 8, 2006|access-date=February 6, 2022|archive-date=February 8, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180208123525/https://www.pghcitypaper.com/pittsburgh/in-between/Content?oid=1337222|url-status=live}}</ref> He started playing music at the age of 12.<ref name="Grand Ole Opry"/> Smyers attended [[Carnegie Mellon University]] with plans to study finance and play football.<ref name="Lenehan Vaughn"/><ref name="pittsburghmagazine"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://lescheminsdurock.wordpress.com/2012/05/12/bonaventure-our-dream-is-to-touch-people-with-our-music/|title=Bonaventure: 'Our dream is to touch people with our music'|publisher=Patriciatanne.com/|date=May 12, 2012|access-date=May 12, 2012|archive-date=November 21, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161121105933/https://lescheminsdurock.wordpress.com/2012/05/12/bonaventure-our-dream-is-to-touch-people-with-our-music/|url-status=live}}</ref> He moved to Nashville in 2010,<ref name=":1" /> after graduating from college the same year.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Where It All Began - Carnegie Mellon University {{!}} CMU |url=https://www.cmu.edu/homepage/creativity/2014/fall/where-it-all-began.shtml#:~:text=Dan%20Smyers?,(TPR%2710)%20said. |access-date=2022-04-06 |website=www.cmu.edu |archive-date=2021-06-13 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210613120339/https://www.cmu.edu/homepage/creativity/2014/fall/where-it-all-began.shtml#:~:text=Dan%20Smyers?,(TPR%2710)%20said. |url-status=live }}</ref> Two years later he would meet Shay.<ref name=":0" />

Prior to joining Dan + Shay, Smyers fronted an [[emo]] band called Transition, which also includes members like Harrison Wargo (who later formed [[The Morning Light]]) and Dustin Hook (who left to join [[My American Heart]] and is now the full-time touring bassist for Dan + Shay ), the band released one full-length record in 2006 on [[Floodgate Records]] produced by [[Mike Herrera]], who is best known for his work with [[MxPx]].<ref name="Lenehan Vaughn"/><ref>{{Cite web|first=Rachael|last=Dowd|url=https://www.altpress.com/news/dan-and-shay-dan-smyers-emo-band-all-time-low/|title=Dan Smyers' emo band before Dan + Shay once opened for All Time Low|website=[[Alternative Press (magazine)|Alternative Press]]|date=January 21, 2021|access-date=February 6, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210128031456/https://www.altpress.com/news/dan-and-shay-dan-smyers-emo-band-all-time-low/|archive-date=January 28, 2021}}</ref> Transition appeared on the [[Vans Warped Tour]] in both 2004 and 2006, and had opened for bands including [[All Time Low]], MxPx, [[Streetlight Manifesto]] & [[Reel Big Fish]]<ref>{{Cite web|url = https://www.setlist.fm/setlist/transition/2006/congress-theater-chicago-il-6bf5da6a.html|title = Transition Setlist at Congress Theater, Chicago|website = setlist.fm|access-date = 2021-01-22|archive-date = 2021-01-28|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20210128075636/https://www.setlist.fm/setlist/transition/2006/congress-theater-chicago-il-6bf5da6a.html|url-status = live}}</ref> He was also in a [[Rock music|rock]] band called Bonaventure.<ref name="Lenehan Vaughn"/><ref name="pittsburghmagazine"/>

Instruments: Vocals, guitar, bass, piano

Smyers and Abby Law were in a relationship for many years before becoming engaged in 2016 and were married on May 13, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|first=Sterling|last=Whitaker|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/dan-and-shay-dan-smyers-married/|title=Dan Smyers of Dan + Shay Gets Married - Taste of Country|website=Taste of Country|date=May 14, 2017|access-date=February 6, 2022|archive-date=February 6, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220206151212/https://tasteofcountry.com/dan-and-shay-dan-smyers-married/|url-status=live}}</ref>  Law made a cameo in a Dan + Shay videos for their songs "Nothin' Like You", "Speechless"<ref>{{cite web|first=Annie|last=Reuter|url=http://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/dan-shay-wedding-song-speechless/|title=Dan + Shay Release Sentimental Wedding Song, 'Speechless'|work=Sounds Like Nashville|date=May 19, 2018|access-date=February 6, 2022|archive-date=December 28, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191228131608/https://www.soundslikenashville.com/news/dan-shay-wedding-song-speechless/|url-status=live}}</ref> and "10,000 Hours".<ref>{{cite magazine|first=Heran|last=Mamo|url=https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/justin-bieber-hailey-bieber-10000-hours-video-dan-shay-8532203/|title=Bask in Justin & Hailey Bieber's Newlywed Bliss in Romantic '10,000 Hours' Video With Dan + Shay|magazine=Billboard|date=October 4, 2019|access-date=February 6, 2022|archive-date=February 6, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220206182808/https://www.billboard.com/music/music-news/justin-bieber-hailey-bieber-10000-hours-video-dan-shay-8532203/|url-status=live}}</ref> Smyers and Abby work with Wags & Walks Rescue Nashville to save dogs and place them in their forever homes.<ref name="Lenehan Vaughn"/><ref name="Dogs">{{cite web|first=Philip|last=Trapp|url=https://tasteofcountry.com/dan-smyers-old-dog-rescue/|title=Dan + Shay's Dan Smyers Rescues Elderly Dog: 'She Was Dealt A Tough Hand'|website=Taste of Country|date=March 5, 2021|access-date=February 6, 2022|archive-date=February 6, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220206182810/https://tasteofcountry.com/dan-smyers-old-dog-rescue/|url-status=live}}</ref> They have five dogs together as of March 2021.<ref name="Dogs"/>

===Shay Mooney===
[[File:Shay Mooney of Dan + Shay in 2017.jpg|thumb|upright=0.9|Shay Mooney]]
James Shay Mooney,<ref name="Lenehan Vaughn"/><ref name="5 Things"/> born {{birth date and age|1991|12|27|mf=y}}<ref name="cafenashville"/> was raised in [[Natural Dam, Arkansas]],<ref>{{cite web|first=Brett|last=Rains|url=https://www.4029tv.com/article/cma-nominee-remembers-growing-up-in-the-river-valley/13452633|title=CMA nominee growing up in the River Valley|website=4029tv|date=November 9, 2017|access-date=February 6, 2022|archive-date=February 6, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220206182822/https://www.4029tv.com/article/cma-nominee-remembers-growing-up-in-the-river-valley/13452633|url-status=live}}</ref> and was home-schooled until the fifth-grade,<ref name="Lenehan Vaughn"/> but later attended [[Union Christian Academy]] and [[Van Buren High School (Van Buren, Arkansas)|Van Buren High School]].<ref name="Lenehan Vaughn"/> At the age of 14, he started writing songs, and at 16, he started learning how to play guitar.<ref name="Grand Ole Opry"/> Following high school, he attended [[University of Valley Forge|Valley Forge Christian College]] for one year before completely pursuing his music career.<ref>{{cite web|first=Pat|last=St.Claire|url=http://cnnradio.cnn.com/2013/03/17/cnn-radio-music-notes-shay-mooney-a-redneck-in-an-urban-world|title=Shay Mooney – 'a redneck in an urban world'|work=Cnnradio.cnn.com|date=March 17, 2013|access-date=February 6, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190605003508/http://cnnradio.cnn.com/2013/03/17/cnn-radio-music-notes-shay-mooney-a-redneck-in-an-urban-world/|archive-date=June 5, 2019}}</ref> Mooney had a record deal with rapper [[T-Pain]] on Pain's [[Nappy Boy Entertainment]] label.<ref name="taste"/><ref name="Lenehan Vaughn"/> However, the deal ended once he formed Dan + Shay.<ref name="Lenehan Vaughn"/>

Instruments: Vocals, piano, guitar

On January 24, 2017, his fiancée Hannah Billingsley gave birth to their first child, a son.<ref name="asher">{{cite web|first=Jen|last=Juneau|url=https://people.com/parents/shay-mooney-hannah-billingsley-welcome-son-asher-james/|title=Shay Mooney and Hannah Billingsley Welcome Son Asher James|work=people.com|date=January 24, 2017|access-date=February 6, 2022|archive-date=September 1, 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240901231351/https://people.com/celebrity-parenting/|url-status=live}}</ref> Mooney and Billingsley were married on October 20, 2017, in Arkansas.<ref name="Hannah Mooney">{{cite web|author1=Sarah Michaud|author2=Brianne Tracy|url=http://people.com/country/shay-mooney-marries-hannah-billingsley/|title=Dan + Shay's Shay Mooney Marries Hannah Billingsley — All the Wedding Details!|work=people.com|date=October 21, 2017|access-date=February 6, 2022|archive-date=November 4, 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211104195631/https://people.com/country/shay-mooney-marries-hannah-billingsley/|url-status=live}}</ref> On February 21, 2020, the couple welcomed their second son.<ref name="ames">{{cite web|author1=Ally Mauch|author2=Sarah Michaud|url=https://people.com/parents/shay-mooney-welcomes-son-ames-alexander-first-photo/|title=Meet Ames Alexander! Dan + Shay's Shay Mooney and Wife Hannah Welcome Second Son|work=people.com|date=February 22, 2020|access-date=February 6, 2022|archive-date=May 23, 2022|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220523045750/https://people.com/parents/shay-mooney-welcomes-son-ames-alexander-first-photo/|url-status=live}}</ref> On January 20, 2023, Billingsley gave birth to the couple's third son.<ref name="abram">{{cite web|author=Angela Andaloro|url=https://people.com/parents/shay-mooney-wife-hannah-welcome-third-baby-boy-son-abram/|title=Shay Mooney and Wife Hannah Welcome Third Baby Boy, Son Abram: 'Grateful Doesn't Begin to Cover It'|work=people.com|date=January 20, 2023|access-date=March 27, 2024|archive-date=September 1, 2024|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20240901231858/https://people.com/parents/shay-mooney-wife-hannah-welcome-third-baby-boy-son-abram/|url-status=live}}</ref>
